content.description:
Dividimusdivido, -ere: to part, divide muros et moenia pandimuspando, -ere = aperio, -ire urbis. 
Accinguntaccingo, -ere: to equip omnes operi pedibusque rotarumrota, -ae, f.: wheel 
subiciuntsubicio, -ere: to place under lapsuslapsus, -us, m.: slipping, et stuppeastuppeus, -a, -um, adj.: made of flax vincula collocollum, -i, n.: neck 
intendunt; scanditscando, -ere = ascendo, -ere fatalis machina muros 

fetafetus, -a, -um, adj.: pregnant armis. Pueri circum innuptaeinnuptus, -a, -um, adj.: unmarriedque puellae 
sacra canunt funemfunis, -is, m.: ropeque manu contingere gaudent; 
illa subitsubeo, -ire: to draw near mediaeque minansminor, -ari: to threaten inlabiturinlabor, -i: to glide in urbi.

Aeneid 2.234-240
content.question:
Answer the following question(s) in English unless the question specifically asks you to provide Latin words.

Identify or describe the grammatical use of the accusative noun moenia (line 1).

frqParts.text:
Answer the following question(s) in English unless the question specifically asks you to provide Latin words.

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2

skill.text: 1.B: Describe how grammar contributes to the meaning and function of Latin words and phrases in context.
